author: _wick
body:
Intel is the most prominent because it used to be Altera but intel bought them. However intel has been in some rocky water with chips recently which points to XLNX doing better. NVDA is another one, but XLNX has specialized in the FPGAs or Field Programmable Gate Arrays and really taken that as their niche. 

The most exciting thing about that is that a lot of electrical engineer journals i read while researching the company stated that there has been no perfect fit for FPGAs yet. What tends to happen is that FPGAs, due to their built in flexibility, are not the optimal piece to use for the final product created by the end user. Generally, the end user can find some other chip that performs the job at a slightly more efficient clip at the end of the production cycle of the product.

Why is that exciting? Well in those same electrical engineering journals they stated that VR and AI may be the best fits for FPGAs, because those technologies need to constantly adapt to their environment and change specifications (especially AI because of machine learning characteristics). Essentially, I see XLNX as a good bet for 5G, which is inevitable, a good bet for automated vehicles, which isn’t too far off, and a good bet for VR and AI, which may never happen. If they do though, XLNX could stand to profit a ton.

author: 2fish24
body: Dropped Apple and moved on to nvidia. They have some stuff cooking plus gpus were sold out through all of quarantine, I think earnings will be insane. I’m expecting either a deal with Xilinx or Arm within the next few months. 3000 series gpus will have a built in AI 100%

author: gaffermanner
body:
Absolutely. Sorry for the late reply. I rarely check Reddit notifications anymore.

Limited it to the best ones. I’ve scaled down the list a bit. Here you go (in no particular order):

Qualcomm

Nvidia

Taiwan Semiconductor Ltd

Ciena Corp

Skyworks

Marvell

Corning

Qorvo Inc.

AMD

Crown Castle

Tower Semiconductor Ltd

Resonant Inc.

Xilinx

Ericsson

Nokia

NXP

American Tower Corp.

author: battousai1130
body: That’s the whole point of FD lottos. This is coming from a guy who lost shit tones on KHC and XLNX calls. Don’t get me wrong , I have position sizes accordingly. This is a lotto. Like 2% of the whole portfolio is max risk.

author: _wick
body: No. I just researched XLNX for about 50-60 hours along with financial modeling for an university organization. Don’t come for me if you invest in the company and lose your money hahaha

author: dzr0001
body:
Intel is trying to compete in GPU with Ponte Vecchio, but that was designed around the Intel 7nm process. I stopped trying to follow whether or not they'd leverage TSMC capacity for that as it seemed to change on a daily basis.

You mentioned the difference between GPUs and accelerators but you do have to keep in mind that the high end GPU products actually just have tensor cores on them anyway. The v100, for example, has 640 tensor cores on it. Since you mentioned Altera, there are also a lot of interesting ML/API capabilities for FPGAs. I think Xilinx is probably the leader in that space but both Intel and Xilinx have to contend with the fact that there is just a lot more IP available for GPU right now, partly due to the Nvidia software catalog.

author: dzr0001
body: Xilinx has spent a lot of money over the last few years directly and through acquisition to create more efficient translation layers so that python and C developers can use their products without having to touch something like verilog. However, they also spent a lot creating tools for marketplaces and licensing so that you can access a market of FPGA IP, but at a cost. Until there's more incentive to have opensource FPGA IP, I don't think adoption is going to be very good.
